g.text: Writing – original draft:
KLR.
Writing – review & editing:
KLR GS DP YG TEW CEF KK.
References
Bamber JL, Riva REM, Vermeersen BLA, LeBrocq AM. Reassessment of the potential sea-level rise
from a collapse of the West Antarctic ice sheet. Science. 2009; 324(5929):901–903. doi: 10.1126/
Pollard D, DeConto RM, Alley RB. Potential Antarctic ice sheet retreat driven by hydrofracturing and ice
cliff failure. Earth and Planetary Science Letters. 2015; 412:112–121.
Ivins ER. Ice sheet stability and sea level. Science. 2009; 324(5929):888–889. doi: 10.1126/science.
Church JA, Clark A, Cazenave JM, Gregory JM, Jevrejeva S, Levermann A, et al. Sea level change. In:
Stocker TF, Qin D, Plattner GK, Tignor M, Allen SK, Boschung J, et al., editors. Climate Change 2013:
The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fifth Assessment Report of the
Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Cambridge, United Kingdom and New York, NY, USA:
Cambridge University Press; 2013
Alley RB, Anandakrishnan S, Christianson K, Horgan HJ, Muto A, Parizek BR, et al. Oceanic forcing of
ice-sheet retreat: West Antarctica and more. Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences. 2015; 43
Mercer JH. Antarctic ice and Sangamon sea level. International Association of Hydrological Sciences.
Mercer JH. West Antarctic ice sheet and CO
greenhouse effect: A threat of disaster. Nature. 1978; 271
DeConto RM, Pollard D. Contribution of Antarctica to past and future sea-level rise. Nature. 2016; 531
Pfeffer WT, Harper JT, O’Neel S. Kinematic constraints on glacier contributions to 21st-century sea-
Oppenheimer M, Campos M, Warren R, Birkmann J, Luber G, O’Neill B, et al. Emergent risks and key
vulnerabilities. In: Field CB, Barros VR, Dokken DJ, Mach KJ, Mastrandrea MD, Bilir TE, et al., editors.
Climate change 2014: Impacts, adaptation, and vulnerability Part A: Global and Sectoral Aspects Con-
tribution of Working Group II to the Fifth assessment report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate
Change. Cambridge, United Kingdom and New York, NY, USA: Cambridge University Press; 2014
Oerlemans J. Antarctic ice volume for the last 740 ka calculated with a simple ice sheet model. Antarctic
Schoof C. Ice sheet grounding line dynamics: Steady states, stability, and hysteresis. Journal of Geo-
physical Research: Earth Surface. 2007; 112(F3):n/a–n/a. F03S28. doi: 10.1029/2006JF000664
Gudmundsson GH. Ice-shelf buttressing and the stability of marine ice sheets. The Cryosphere. 2013;
Shaffer G. Formulation, calibration and validation of the DAIS model (version 1), a simple Antarctic ice
sheet model sensitive to variations of sea level and ocean subsurface temperature. Geoscientific Model
Little CM, Oppenheimer M, Urban NM. Upper bounds on twenty-first-century Antarctic ice loss
assessed using a probabilistic framework. Nature Climate Change. 2013; 3(7):654–659. doi: 10.1038/
nclimate1845
Kopp RE, Horton RM, Little CM, Mitrovica JX, Oppenheimer M, Rasmussen DJ, et al. Probabilistic 21st
and 22nd century sea-level projections at a global network of tide-gauge sites. Earth’s Future. 2014; 2
Golledge NR, Kowalewski DE, Naish TR, Levy RH, Fogwill CJ, Gasson EGW. The multi-millennial Ant-
arctic commitment to future sea-level rise. Nature. 2015; 526(7573):421–425. doi: 10.1038/
nature15706 PMID: 26469052
Ritz C, Edwards TL, Durand G, Payne AJ, Peyaud V, Hindmarsh RCA. Potential sea-level rise from Ant-
arctic ice-sheet instability constrained by observations. Nature. 2015; 528(7580):115–118. doi: 10.
Rahmstorf S. A semi-empirical approach to projecting future sea-level rise. Science. 2007; 315
Assessing the Impact of Antarctic Retreat Mechanisms
